Sheet1.author: Jay Root
Sheet1.headline: The Widow vs. the Insurer: A Wife's Fight for Her Family's Future
Sheet1.story_summary: After Crystal Davis’ husband, Wayne Davis, died, the state ruled his death a workplace fatality and awarded her family benefits under the workers’ compensation system. The insurance company originally fought the order in court, and its lawyers even sued her two young children to take away their half of the proceeds. After Crystal Davis’ story was featured in The Texas Tribune, the insurance company dropped its lawsuit against her and her children.

Sheet1.author: Jim Malewitz
Sheet1.headline: Dissecting Denton: How a Texas City Banned Fracking
Sheet1.story_summary: State lawmakers, the oil and gas industry and national environmental groups have asked deep questions about Denton, home to two universities, 277 gas wells and, now, thanks to a group of local activists, Texas’ first ban on fracking.

Sheet1.author: Morgan Smith
Sheet1.headline: Patrick, Now in Driver's Seat, Credits Grass Roots
Sheet1.story_summary: State Sen. Dan Patrick has credited his success to grassroots support. But the Houston Republican's momentum was also built on lessons learned navigating the old-school politics of Harris County.

Sheet1.author: Reeve Hamilton
Sheet1.headline: After 48 Years, Whitman's Unborn Victim Gets a Headstone
Sheet1.story_summary: Nearly 48 years after Charles Whitman's notorious shooting rampage on the University of Texas at Austin campus, his youngest victim — a baby still in utero — finally received a headstone this year.

Sheet1.author: Neena Satija
Sheet1.headline: No Joke: Most Drinking Supplies Flush With "Potty Water"
Sheet1.story_summary: Wichita Falls became the butt of late-night jokes and the subject of shocked headlines over plans to use treated sewer water as drinking water. But the town is hardly the only one to reuse dirty water.

Sheet1.author: Julián Aguilar
Sheet1.headline: Against the Odds, Finding Refuge in El Paso
Sheet1.story_summary: Four years after fleeing Somalia, Dekha Hassan-Mohamed is living in El Paso after winning an asylum claim and bucking a national trend. Her lawyer is seeking the same protection for another client who fled Nigeria. Both women are grateful for the new chapters of their lives in El Paso.

Sheet1.author: Alexa Ura
Sheet1.headline: Ebola Response Puts Jenkins in Spotlight, Again
Sheet1.story_summary: After the first case of Ebola in the U.S. was confirmed in Dallas, Dallas County Judge Clay Jenkins was thrust into the national spotlight.

Sheet1.author: Terri Langford
Sheet1.headline: Timeline: A History of Lethal Drug Use in Texas
Sheet1.story_summary: Texas used a three-drug lethal injection cocktail for nearly three decades. But since 2011, a dwindling drug supply has forced Texas and other states to find other drugs to administer the death penalty.

Sheet1.author: Aman Batheja
Sheet1.headline: Local Debt Climbs as Texas Cities Deal With Growth
Sheet1.story_summary: Texas cities, counties and school districts are relying more on debt to maintain services in a fast-growing state. While critics argue communities need to work harder to live within their means, local officials say the issue is not that simple.

Sheet1.author: Christine Ayala
Sheet1.headline: New Culprit Threatens a Park's Rebirth Years After Fire
Sheet1.story_summary: As shrubs and seedlings take hold in the scorched Bastrop State Park, park officials face a new quandary: An abundance of whitetail deer is threatening the new growth.

Sheet1.author: Bobby Blanchard
Sheet1.headline: In Texas, a New Kind of Space Race Emerges
Sheet1.story_summary: As states compete to become the center of private space flight, SpaceX could change the game in Texas. Helped by hefty public incentives, the company is building a new facility near Brownsville.

Sheet1.author: Edgar Walters
Sheet1.headline: "3-Strikes" Plan Spurs Nursing Home Regulation Debate
Sheet1.story_summary: Legislators in 2015 are poised to take up a proposal that would have the state close nursing homes that rack up high-level federal violations on three separate days over a two-year period.

Sheet1.author: Alana Rocha and Justin Dehn
Sheet1.headline: Video: Program Unites Veterans Behind Bars
Sheet1.story_summary: They served their country, then ended up on the wrong side of the law. Many of the more than 10,000 Texas veterans serving time behind bars say they attempted to erase the images of war through illegal drug use and got caught, sometimes more than once. A new Texas Department of Criminal Justice program is giving a group of veterans the resources and guidance to stay out of the legal system upon their release.

Sheet1.author: Becca Aaronson
Sheet1.headline: The Shale Life
Sheet1.story_summary: The Shale Life is a multimedia project that explores how an explosion in oil and gas production has changed lives and fortunes across Texas. Nearly a dozen Tribune staffers contributed to the project, which took six months to complete.

Sheet1.author: Ryan Murphy
Sheet1.headline: Disappearing Rio Grande
Sheet1.story_summary: The Rio Grande has been the lifeblood of the valleys and civilizations it flowed through for more than 3,000 years. As cities and farms suck it dry and a warming climate makes it evaporate faster, the river's future has never been more uncertain. Reporter Colin McDonald is traveling the length of the Rio Grande, interviewing those who depend on and control it, taking photos and videos, and cataloging the chemistry and biology of the river from the Rocky Mountains to the Gulf of Mexico.

Sheet1.author: John Reynolds
Sheet1.headline: From State of Pappy and Kinky, SpicyBrown Runs for Senate
Sheet1.story_summary: Green Party candidate Emily Sanchez had few resources in her failed bid for U.S. Senate. What she did have was a nickname, SpicyBrown, that voters saw on the ballot.

Sheet1.author: David Muto
Sheet1.headline: In Sprawling Texas, Walkability Gains a Toehold
Sheet1.story_summary: Advocates for more pedestrian-friendly urban cores and communities say interest in making Texas cities more walkable is on the rise — a shift spurred in part by changing demographics and the state’s growing population.

Sheet1.author: Corrie MacLaggan
Sheet1.headline: Brenham Synagogue Moving to Austin, and a New Life
Sheet1.story_summary: In Leon Toubin's dreams, Jewish life would again be vibrant in Brenham, where he cares for the synagogue where generations of his family worshipped. But Jews are not moving to Brenham, so Toubin has arranged to move Texas' oldest Orthodox synagogue to Austin.
